title: What Can You Do to Prevent Mold & Mildew on Your Shower Curtain?

steps.title: Wash your shower curtain, liner, rod, and rings once per month.
steps.content: Wash your shower curtain, liner, rod, and rings once per month. Cleaning your shower curtain on a regular basis helps prevent mold from growing. [1] X Research source To make this process easier, it’s best to use machine-washable shower curtains . Here’s how to wash each individual component: Fabric curtain: Wash the curtain in your washing machine according to the instructions on the care label, and add 1 cup (236 mL) of vinegar during the rinse cycle. Let the curtain air dry. Plastic liner: Put the plastic liner in the washing machines with some bath towels, and wash them on a delicate cycle with cold water. Add ½ cup (136 g) baking soda and 1 ⁄ 4 cup (59 ml) vinegar during the rinse cycle. Allow the liner to air dry—the heat from the dryer can melt it. Rod and rings: Spray the rod and rings with a commercial bathroom cleaner or an all-purpose cleaner. Wipe them down with a clean cloth to remove residue. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Spray down the liner with a bathroom cleaner on a weekly basis.
steps.content: Spray down the liner with a bathroom cleaner on a weekly basis. This can prevent mold and mildew from forming on your liner in between washes. Simply spray it with a store-bought bathroom cleaner , or a DIY cleaning solution of equal parts warm water and distilled white vinegar. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Keep the liner inside the tub and the curtain outside the tub.
steps.content: Keep the liner inside the tub and the curtain outside the tub. This prevents moisture from getting trapped between the two components, and it also allows them each to dry more quickly. Both of these things are crucial for mold prevention. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Dry your shower curtain after each use.
steps.content: Dry your shower curtain after each use. Mold can form when moisture is allowed to sit on a surface for a long time, so it’s a good idea to dry your shower curtain and liner after you shower. This will help prevent soap scum, mold, and mildew from growing. [5] X Research source Use a dry towel or rag to remove water from the wet side of your shower curtain after you shower. Shake out the liner and separate any folds in the curtain to release trapped moisture, as well.

steps.title: Squeegee your shower after each use and wipe wet surfaces.
steps.content: Squeegee your shower after each use and wipe wet surfaces. Mold can easily spread from one area of your bathroom to another, so it’s important to prevent it from growing in your shower and on other surfaces. Use a squeegee to wipe down your shower walls, and use a clean, dry cloth to wipe any other surfaces in your bathroom that are wet or have condensation on them. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Hang up wet bath mats, towels, and washcloths after showering.
steps.content: Hang up wet bath mats, towels, and washcloths after showering. If you leave wet towels, wash cloths, or bath mats bunched up on the floor, they won’t dry quickly, which can lead to mold growth and spread. [7] X Trustworthy Source United States Environmental Protection Agency Independent U.S. government agency responsible for promoting safe environmental practices Go to source In order to prevent this, hang these wet items up on your towel rack after showering, so they can dry completely.

steps.title: Keep the humidity in your bathroom between 35-50%.
steps.content: Keep the humidity in your bathroom between 35-50%. “Mold is generated by humidity, so you should be reducing that to a minimum,” explains Ragnolo. To prevent your bathroom from becoming humid while you shower, make sure the area is well ventilated. If you can, leave the bathroom door open and crack a window. It also helps to turn on the exhaust fan and leave it on until about 30 minutes after your shower is over. [8] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source If your bathroom still feels too humid after trying these methods, consider using a small dehumidifier . It can help keep the humidity level in your bathroom below 50%, which is key for preventing mold. [9] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Deep clean your bathroom regularly.
steps.content: Deep clean your bathroom regularly. To prevent mold from growing on your shower curtain and liner, it’s important to keep your bathroom mold-free in general. [10] X Trustworthy Source United States Environmental Protection Agency Independent U.S. government agency responsible for promoting safe environmental practices Go to source The best way to do this is to deep clean your bathroom on a regular basis, preferably once per week. [11] X Trustworthy Source Consumer Reports Nonprofit organization dedicated to consumer advocacy and product testing Go to source During your cleaning session, make sure to spray down the counters, sink, and interior of your shower with a cleaning solution to get rid of soap scum and prevent mildew from forming. Wash bath mats, bath towels, wash cloths, and hand towels in your washing machine and dry them thoroughly before putting them back. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Mold grows on shower curtains because they get wet frequently.
steps.content: Mold grows on shower curtains because they get wet frequently. “Every day, the shower curtain gets wet,” explains Kapur. “Moisture always goes there,” and mold needs moisture to thrive. Beyond this, mold tends to grow in warm, damp areas, so your bathroom becomes the perfect breeding ground for it when it gets hot and steamy from your shower. There are thousands of known species of mold, so you won’t be able to identify the specific type of mold that’s grown in your home without sending it to a lab to be analyzed, explains Kapur. All mold can be harmful to your health, so you'll need to remove it regardless. The most common types of mold that grow inside people's homes are Cladosporium , Penicillium , and Aspergillus. [13] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source Kapur adds that, most of the time, shower curtains will grow mildew, rather than full-on mold. Mildew is technically categorized as mold, but he describes it as “a nicer cousin of mold” because it doesn’t entrench itself as deeply on surfaces, so it's easier to remove.

steps.title: It’s important to prevent mold because it can cause health problems.
steps.content: It’s important to prevent mold because it can cause health problems. A colony of mold releases spores and microscopic toxins called mycotoxins into the air, which you can then breathe in. Prolonged exposure to these toxins and spores can cause a runny nose, coughing, congestion, headaches, skin rashes, asthma and changes to your immune system. Because of this, it’s crucial to prevent mold growth and eliminate it if it does show up in your home. People who already have asthma, are allergic to mold, are immune compromised, or have lung disease are more at risk for having negative reactions to mold. [14] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: If mold grows on a shower curtain, it’s best to throw it away.
steps.content: If mold grows on a shower curtain, it’s best to throw it away. Mold is almost impossible to remove completely because it grows into the empty spaces and crevices on porous surfaces. [15] X Trustworthy Source United States Environmental Protection Agency Independent U.S. government agency responsible for promoting safe environmental practices Go to source As a result, the mold may come back and spread, even if you try to thoroughly clean your moldy shower curtain and liner.

steps.title: To try to clean a moldy curtain or liner, soak it in a bleach solution.
steps.content: To try to clean a moldy curtain or liner, soak it in a bleach solution. If you’re really opposed to throwing away your moldy curtain and/or liner, your best course of action will probably be soaking it in a bleach solution. Fill a large bucket or your bathtub with water, and add 1 ⁄ 4 cup (59 mL) bleach per each gallon of water. Soak the curtain for at least 8 hours. [16] X Research source Make sure the area is well ventilated, so you’re not exposed to bleach fumes. Open windows and make sure there’s lots of fresh air circulating in the room. [17] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source If your shower curtain still has mold on it after soaking, or if the mold grows back quickly, it’s best to toss it out and replace it. Keep in mind that this method will likely only be possible for plastic curtains and liners, since bleach may discolor fabric curtains.
